name: Noya
headline: Radically reducing capital costs and build time for direct air capture
description: Noya is radically reducing the upfront capital costs and installation time required to perform direct air capture. We're doing this by retrofitting existing pieces of industrial equipment like cooling towers and turning them into CO2 capture machines.

founders.name: Josh Santos, Founder
founders.description: co-founder/chief carbon removal officer at noya. sailor, house dj, runner, best snowboarder on the mountain. my sweet tooth is my achilles heel.

generated_description:
Noya is a bold startup founded in 2020, aiming to transform the landscape of carbon capture technology. Located in San Francisco and starting as part of Y Combinator's Winter 2021 cohort, Noya's mission is straightforward yet ambitious: to radically reduce the capital costs and installation time associated with direct air capture (DAC) systems.

So, what’s the idea? Noya retrofits existing industrial equipment—think cooling towers—transforming them into machines that suck CO2 right out of the air. This innovative approach not only makes the technology more accessible but offers a pragmatic solution to one of the climate crisis’s most pressing challenges.

With a small team of just 12 employees, Noya is headed by Aaron Epstein as their Group Partner. The company emphasizes energy efficiency and modular design, seeking to deploy all-electric, water-positive direct air capture systems that could also generate clean water while tackling excess CO2.

The company has garnered attention from industry leaders, including Shopify, who see great promise in Noya’s approach. Its technology stands out for being cost-effective, innovative, and aiming for carbon negativity—moving beyond merely reducing emissions to actively removing carbon from the atmosphere.

In a world with increasing urgency around climate issues, Noya is inviting partnerships and collaboration to push this critical technology forward. If you care about the future of the planet and want to get involved, Noya might just be the company to watch.

Check out more about their initiatives and how they work on their [website](https://noya.co).
